qas.question: Do i have to pay for quarantine costs in vietnam?

answers.text: The Vietnamese government has confirmed that anyone entering Vietnam from 1 September 2020 must pay for quarantine costs both in government centres and in designated hotels.

qas.question: Do i have to pay for covid hospital treatment costs in vietnam?

answers.text: You will also be responsible for paying for any coronavirus hospital treatment costs.

paragraphs.context: The Vietnamese government has confirmed that anyone entering Vietnam from 1 September 2020 must pay for quarantine costs both in government centres and in designated hotels. You will also be responsible for paying for any coronavirus hospital treatment costs.

qas.question: How long do i have to quarantine in vietnam for?

answers.text: You should expect to go into quarantine for at least 14 days. Fully vaccinated visitors may be permitted to leave after 7 days with a further 7 days at a place of residence.

paragraphs.context: Vietnam’s quarantine requirements are mandated by the Vietnamese Ministry of Health. The British Embassy and Consulate General are unable to intervene in having these requirements waived, shortened or changed or assist in the reservation of, or transfer to, hotels used for quarantine. Violations carry strict penalties. You should expect to go into quarantine for at least 14 days. Fully vaccinated visitors may be permitted to leave after 7 days with a further 7 days at a place of residence. Quarantine will be longer if you test positive at any point. If you test positive, you should expect to be treated in a Vietnamese hospital. Asymptomatic patients may be discharged from hospital after 10 days and have 2 back to back negative COVID-19 tests. Once discharged you will be expected to undertake a period of self-isolation for 14 days and should follow the instructions issued by the local authorities.

qas.question: What are the restrictions in vietnam?

answers.text: The measures to combat COVID-19 vary from province to province and can change at short notice.

paragraphs.context: Public spaces and services- The measures to combat COVID-19 vary from province to province and can change at short notice. Vietnam has introduced a colour-coded categorisation to identify high risk COVID areas across Vietnam. These categories can vary between provinces and within cities. The categories are: Red, Orange, Yellow, and Green. The Vietnamese authorities regularly review the categorisations. Restrictions will differ depending on the categorisation of particular districts within cities. You should be ready to comply with local authorities. You should also ensure that you have your ID/passport with you. Before travelling to another province you should check with your travel provider and/or accommodation what requirements are in place, both where you are travelling to and on return. Some provinces may require negative COVID-19 tests to be obtained before and/or after entry and some may impose periods of self-isolation.

qas.question: Do i need to wear a mask in vietnam?

answers.text: Mask wearing is compulsory in public settings. Those not wearing masks may be liable to spot fines.

qas.question: What should i do if i test positive for covid-19 in vietnam?

answers.text: If you test positive with COVID-19 you will have to self-isolate for 7 days.

qas.question: What do i do if i come in contact with someone with covid-19 in vietnam?

answers.text: If you become a close contact of someone with COVID-19, you will have to self-isolate for 7 days, at your place of residence, if it meets the requirements of local health authorities, or at a quarantine centre.
